headline: Bobcats 91, Nets 84
summary: The Nets came back from a seven-point deficit with just over a minute left in regulation, but faded in overtime to lose to the Bobcats Friday night in Charlotte.

headline: Rangers 2, Islanders 0
summary: Defenseman Marc Staal's hard shot from the blue line at 4:33 into the second period was enough for the Rangers to beat the rival Islanders at Madison Square Garden.

headline: What's Hot…and Not
summary: A graphical look at how different investments, from REIT shares to crude oil, fared last week.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Schweitzer-Mauduit International, Orexigen Therapeutics: Biggest Price Decliners (SWM, OREX)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Cisco Systems, JPMorgan Chase: Money Flow Leaders (CSCO, JPM)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Japanese Yields Rise
summary: Japanese government bond yields crept higher Friday as investors awaited the U.S. jobs report that was released well after the close.

headline: Violence in the Niger Delta
summary: Violence in Nigeria's oil-rich Niger Delta dropped after a government-sponsored amnesty program. However, some groups remain armed in the delta's winding creeks.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & amplifications for Dec. 3, 2010.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Dec. 3, 2010

headline: Rangers 6, Islanders 5
summary: Gaborik's third goal of the game proved the winner for the Blueshirts.

headline: Canadiens 5, Devils 1
summary: Two quick goals doom Devils, who lost for the first time in five games at home.

headline: Special Occasion Brunch
summary: Lincoln, the new Italian restaurant from chef Jonathan Benno, may be the ritziest brunch on the Upper West Side.

headline: Avian Influenza in Asia
summary: The Japanese government Friday confirmed the country's first outbreak in three years of a high-risk bird flu, though it stressed that there was no evidence the disease had spread beyond chickens. Hong Kong saw a human case two weeks ago.

headline: Market Report
summary: Photographs by Boyle + Gardner; soft-good styling by Anastasia Marano

headline: UES Loft Space
summary: Though the owners didn't make any extensive changes to this huge Loft 67 condo on the Upper East Side, they took a few measures to tone down the modern feel of the home.

headline: Market Report
summary: Photographs by Boyle + Gardner; soft-good styling by Anastasia Marano

headline: A Garden Grows
summary: What can an idea, two decades and an unrelenting passion accomplish? Take a gander at Patrice Taravella's garden.

headline: Clinton Expresses Concern Over Network Sharing
summary: The secretary of state, addressing security concerns raised by the WikiLeaks document release, cited a Bush administration decision to add State Department cables to a Defense Department network.

headline: U.N. Nuclear Official Denies He Takes Orders From U.S.
summary: The chief of the United Nations' nuclear watchdog pushed back against charges he takes his orders from the U.S., as the leaks of secret State Department cables continue to rankle the world's diplomatic corps.

headline: CVS Hiring Hits Bump
summary: A judge temporarily blocked CVS Caremark's hiring of a new president of retail operations after Wal-Mart filed a lawsuit to prevent his employment.

headline: Antique Shopping in London
summary: Shopper extraordinaire and city native Rita Konig takes us into her favorite places for antiques. Even factoring in shipping, buying here can be much less expensive than at home.

headline: Financial Briefing Book: Dec. 4-5
summary: Financial Briefing Book: Dec. 4-5

headline: Citi Loses a Muni-Fund Case
summary: A unit of Citigroup must pay a group of investors a total of $2.43 million for losses they incurred in a municipal arbitrage fund that lost about 80% during a period between 2007 and 2008.

headline: Thrifts Post Fifth-Straight Quarterly Profit
summary: U.S. thrifts reported a $1.77 billion profit for the July-September quarter, up from $1.24 billion in the year-ago period.

headline: Coty Nears Deal for Chinese Skin-Care Firm
summary: Fragrance giant Coty is nearing a deal to purchase Chinese skin-care company TJOY for about $400 million, in what would cap a three-week acquisition binge by the closely held firm.

headline: Currency Quiz
summary: None

headline: Turkey Helps Fight Israeli Fire
summary: Turkey, Greece and others came to Israel's aid Friday in combating a deadly forest fire outside of Haifa, sending firefighting aircraft over what has become the worst fire disaster in Israel's history.

headline: Dow Pulls Out of Doldrums
summary: Stocks closed higher after trading lower for most of the day following a weak jobs report. The Dow climbed 2.6% this week.

headline: Tax Proposal Clouds Year-End Gifts
summary: Recent Senate legislation has estate planners asking whether the window has closed for clients to make gifts to children and grandchildren at unusually low tax rates.

headline: Oil Climbs Above $89 a Barrel
summary: Crude hit another two-year high as a falling dollar and concerns that global oil supplies may be tightening trumped a weak report on U.S. employment.

headline: Viacom Appeals YouTube Case
summary: Viacom filed its appeal of a June ruling in favor of Google's YouTube video site, the latest move in the companies' ongoing battle over alleged copyright infringement.

headline: Agency Mortgages' Slump Accelerates on Jobs Data
summary: Foreign investors accelerated their retreat from the agency mortgage market as weak job-market numbers suggested a rebound in the U.S. housing market is farther away than previously believed.

headline: After China, Brazil Tackles Bubble
summary: Brazil's central bank rolled out a series of measures to tame rapid credit growth, a move that follows similar efforts by China .

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's pictures, a deadly forest fire leaves ashes in Israel, a sinkhole partially swallows a car in Maryland, a boy dives into floodwaters in Venezuela and more.

headline: Cathay Pacific CEO Steps Down
summary: Cathay Pacific's CEO will leave the airline at the end of March to head up the Swiss-based International Air Transport Association.

headline: UBS Finance Chief to Leave
summary: John Cryan will leave next year for personal reasons and will be succeeded by Tom Naratil, financial and risk chief at the Swiss bank's U.S. brokerage unit.

headline: The Empire Strikes Back
summary: Over the past several decades, Turkey has suffered from a lost-empire inferiority complex. But with a robust new economy and an ever-emboldened prime minister, the country feels well on its way to regional super-powerdom.

headline: IckyLeaks
summary: First he posted that helicopter footage. Then he exposed Berlusconi as a lecher. But now he has gone too far, with shocking revelations from the personal diary of Tracy Ann Westfield, in Reply to All.

headline: Senate to Vote on Middle-Class Tax Cuts
summary: A bipartisan group formed to negotiate tax-cut extensions won't meet until after the Senate votes on extending them for the middle-class. A vote is scheduled for Saturday.

headline: SEC Says Rules Would Hit Few Derivatives Traders
summary: Agency staff said no more than about 10 firms that aren't derivatives dealers are likely to be deemed risky enough to require heavy federal oversight.

headline: For Troops at Bagram, a Surprise
summary: President Obama made a surprise visit to Bagram Air Force Base in Afghanistan late Friday, a year after expanding the U.S. mission in the country and just in time for the holidays.

headline: BP: Spill Rate Lower Than Estimates
summary: BP says that estimates of how much oil flowed from its failed Gulf of Mexico well are likely "inflated by a significant amount," aiming to lower by billions of dollars the fines it faces.

headline: India Gold Imports Likely Up 46%
summary: India's gold imports this year are likely to be 700 metric tons, about 46% more than in 2009, as higher farm output and product prices encouraged farmers to invest in the yellow metal and boosted local consumption.

headline: Retail Hiring Slowed in November
summary: Retailers didn't hire as many new workers in November as they traditionally do at this time of year despite signs that consumers are spending more, a government snapshot indicated.

headline: Noda Favors Letting Stock Tax Breaks Expire
summary: Japan's finance minister said he wants to end tax breaks for stock investments at the end of next year, as scheduled, although he indicated he is open to further debate.

headline: World Cup Headed to Russia and Qatar
summary: Soccer's world governing body awarded the 2018 Cup to Russia and the 2022 Cup to Qatar, leaving fans in England and the U.S. disappointed.

headline: Brazil Bank Stocks Tripped Up; European Shares Slip
summary: Brazil's banking stocks fell sharply after the central bank took steps to slow rampant bank lending, whle stocks in Europe fell for the first time in three sessions following a disappointing U.S. jobs report.

headline: Jordan Intervenes in U.S. Terror-Fund Suits
summary: Jordan is stepping up efforts to shield its biggest bank, Arab Bank, from several lawsuits in New York that claim it helped fund terrorist operations, arguing that recent court moves could be ruinous for the bank and "potentially calamitous" for Middle East finance.

headline: A Primped and Pampered Monster
summary: The 2011 Jaguar XJ Supersport hits a sweet spot between galling luxury and serious performance. Think of it as a car that drinks Champagne and then eats the glass. The Journal's Dan Neil has his review.

headline: Bolivia Passes Bill Nationalizing Pension
summary: Bolivia's Congress on Friday approved a bill to nationalize the country's pension-fund system, increase benefits and lower the minimum retirement age.

headline: U.K. Ex-Lawmaker Pleads Guilty in Expenses Scandal
summary: Former U.K. Labour lawmaker David Chaytor has pleaded guilty to three charges of false accounting, becoming the first politician to be convicted in the U.K.'s parliamentary expenses scandal.

headline: Deficit Spending Is Top Worry in New Poll
summary: By 59% to 30%, Americans believe that Congress should cut federal spending rather than raise taxes.

headline: 'The 3rd I' Surgery
summary: NYU Professor Wafaa Bilal has found that having a camera implanted in his head is "uncomfortable for sure." He had the procedure done not at a hospital, but at a piercing studio that specializes in body modification.

headline: European Stocks Slide After U.S. Data
summary: European stocks fell for the first time in three sessions following a disappointing U.S. jobs report. The Stoxx Europe 600 index ended down 0.2% at 270.94, leaving it with a gain of 1.6% for the week, its best weekly showing in a month.

headline: Snow in Europe Shuts Airports, Kills Eight
summary: Heavy snow and subzero temperatures swept across Europe, killing at least eight people in Poland, closing major airports and causing delays to rail and road traffic.

headline: Amazon: WikiLeaks Violated Terms
summary: Amazon stopped hosting WikiLeaks from its Web servers this week because the controversial group violated its terms of service, the Internet company said.

headline: Fashion Classics
summary: Photographs by Jenny Gage and Tom Betterton; styling by Mari David

headline: Exchanges Want Circuit-Breaker Test Extended
summary: Stock exchanges next week are expected to ask regulators to extend for four additional months a circuit breaker pilot program for limiting price swings in some stocks.

headline: Rio Tinto Widens China Ventures
summary: Rio Tinto has set up a new exploration joint venture and extended another existing venture with Chinese partners holding the rest.

headline: Inside the Ferry House
summary: Bryan Ferry's bohemian penchant for mixing and matching is on brilliant display in his London apartment.

headline: Trichet: Governments Need to Be Flexible
summary: European Central Bank chief Jean-Claude Trichet called on governments to do what it takes to get the euro zone out of its debt problems, by strengthening fiscal discipline and ramping up financial support if needed.

headline: Ellison Says Oracle Will 'Go After' H-P
summary: Oracle CEO Larry Ellison said his company will use new hardware to attack onetime partner Hewlett-Packard in the market for server systems.

headline: Google to Buy New York Office Building
summary: Google has signed a contract to buy the building that houses its New York City offices, in a deal that values the property at close to $1.9 billion.

headline: Canada Jobless Rate Falls Unexpectedly
summary: Canada's economy created fewer than expected jobs last month but the jobless rate fell unexpectedly to the lowest level in almost two years, as fewer youth participated in the labor market.

headline: Bulgaria's Finance Minister  Bullish Over Economy
summary: Bulgaria's finance minister Simeon Djankov denied that his government was trying to sidestep more painful spending cuts by basing next year's deficit reduction targets on optimistic growth forecasts.

headline: Yankees Near Deal With Rivera
summary: The Yankees are on the verge of re-signing legendary closer Mariano Rivera to a two-year contract that will pay him roughly $30 million.

headline: Brazil Bank Stocks Slide
summary: Brazil's banking stocks dropped after the central bank took steps to slow rampant bank lending, which analysts said reduces any imminent threat of interest-rate increases.

headline: Australian Miner Legend Looks to Cash In
summary: Legend International is seeking as much as $1 billion for its phosphate mines, as the Australian miner makes plans for a fertilizer complex.

headline: EU Raids Drug Companies
summary: U.K.-based AstraZeneca and Swiss drug maker Nycomed confirmed that European Union regulators had raided some of their offices this week in connection with an antitrust probe.

headline: Services Sector Expands
summary: The U.S. nonmanufacturing sector expanded in November, according to ISM data, but factory orders fell for the first time in four months in October.

headline: Report: Drama in Qantas Cockpit
summary: After a Qantas Airways superjumbo jet suffered an engine blowout at 7,000 feet last month, its pilots faced warnings of potential difficulties with two other engines and other problems, according to a report.

headline: London Copper Weakens
summary: Copper softened on Friday as weaker-than-expected U.S. jobs data dented confidence in the demand outlook, but it held near record highs, with the dollar's losses after the figures capping some of the decline.

headline: Portugal's Banks Face Downgrade
summary: Standard & Poor's could downgrade Portugal's banks shortly over the gloomy economic outlook for the country, a move that would put further pressure on their ability to borrow money, at least at lower costs.

headline: England Dominate Australia on Day One
summary: England, with their main strike bowler James Anderson playing wonderfully well, had Australia reeling at the start of the second Ashes test in Adelaide before finally bowling them out for a below-par score of 245, writes the Times' Michael Atherton.

headline: Regulator Not Satisfied With Airlines' Reasons on High Fares
summary: India's aviation regulator isn't satisfied with clarifications from local carriers on recent fare increase and will now meet them individually to settle the matter, the Ministry of Civil Aviation said.

headline: Euro-Zone Economy Gathers Pace
summary: Euro-zone private-sector activity gathered pace in November, but stark differences remain between larger countries and financially-stressed one, a survey showed.

headline: Sarkozy's India Delegation
summary: French President Nicolas Sarkozy arrives to India along with a delegation including Parliamentarians, senior officials, industrialists and business leaders. Some snapshots.

headline: Bundesbank Upbeat On Germany's Outlook
summary: Germany's economy has at least another two years of solid growth ahead of it, bringing joblessness down to its lowest level in 20 years, the Deutsche Bundesbank said.

headline: Two Indian Cigarette Makers Suspend Production
summary: Godfrey Phillips India and ITC suspended production across all their cigarette manufacturing plants in the country, after a government deadline requiring more graphic warnings on the harmful effects of smoking came into effect Wednesday.

headline: U.K. Service-Sector Growth Slows
summary: The U.K.'s dominant services sector expanded at a marginally slower pace in November than October, weighed down by weak confidence and job cuts,

headline: Asia Ends Mixed; Samsung Surges
summary: Asian stock markets ended mixed Friday as optimism over the European Central Bank's decision to continue providing short-term liquidity to banks was countered by caution ahead of U.S. payrolls data due later in the day. The Nikkei was up 0.1%

headline: Sarkozy's India Visit
summary: On Saturday French President Nicolas Sarkozy arrives to India for a four-day visit with his wife Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, government officials and many other dignitaries. Some snapshots of the itinerary.

headline: China Harvests Record Grain Crop
summary: China reported a grain harvest of 546.41 million metric tons, the seventh consecutive annual record and an increase of 2.9% from last year's crop—which is expected to relieve upward pressure on prices.

headline: EU Wants 4G by 2013
summary: The European Commission wants radio spectrum for wireless broadband -- also known as the fourth-generation mobile network -- available by 2013, it said in a Memo ahead of the EU Telecom Ministers' meeting.

headline: Nissan's Leaf to Launch in Japan Dec. 20
summary: Nissan Motor said it will start selling its Leaf electric vehicle from Dec. 20 in Japan, hoping to become a leader in the electric car market.

headline: Tata: Nano Sales Drop Not Linked to Safety
summary: Tata Motors said a recent drop in the sales of the Nano minicar is more related to issues of sales and financing infrastructure in small towns than safety concerns or production constraints.

headline: Chinese Oil Firms Seal Venezuelan Pacts
summary: China's three main state-owned oil companies strengthened their ties to Venezuela's energy sector, signing six agreements and increasing their investments to a planned $40 billion.

headline: U.S. Envoy Tells of India Battle 'Doctrine'
summary: India's army has a strategy to rapidly respond to a terrorist attack emanating from Pakistan without triggering a nuclear war, the U.S. ambassador wrote in a leaked cable.

headline: IMF: Tougher Measures for Hong Kong Property Prices
summary: The International Monetary Fund on Friday welcomed the Hong Kong government's latest policies to curb property speculation, but warned tougher measures might have to be used to avoid a "protracted and painful downturn."

headline: Kan Struggles to Maintain Power
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Naoto Kan struggles, after less than six months in office, to manage a divided parliament and contain a growing fissure within his own ruling party.

headline: China Opposes Any Provocative Military Acts
summary: China Premier Wen Jiabao said the country opposes any provocative military acts, but has declined to blame Pyongyang for the deadly skirmish with South Korea.

headline: Pertamina, Exxon Sign Deal to Develop Gas Project
summary: Pertamina and Exxon Mobil signed a preliminary agreement to co-develop the offshore East Natuna Block, paving the way to extract natural gas from the massive block located in the South China Sea.

headline: Global Retailers Eye Majority Stake in Matahari
summary: Four global retailers, including South Korea's Lotte Shopping Co., have expressed interest in buying a majority stake in the hypermart business of Indonesian retailer Matahari.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: Rehearsals for Navy Day celebrations, the replica of the Taj Mahal near Ahmedabad, Kashmir's Dal Lake and more.

headline: Yankees Increase Offer to Jeter
summary: The Yankees have improved their initial contract offer of three years and $45 million, according to a person briefed on the talks.

headline: ECB in Credit Market Boost
summary: The European Central Bank redoubled its efforts to shore up the credit markets of vulnerable euro-area countries through government bond purchases.

headline: Basic Hunting Instinct
summary: A slew of new TV shows about auctions and other treasure hunts are attracting record audiences. The economy is not the only reason.

headline: What's On Around Europe
summary: The Weekend Journal's guide to exhibitions, concerts and events across Europe.

headline: Living Happily in the Past
summary: Like her novels, author Jan Karon's restored Virginia estate hews to an earlier era.

headline: Viacom Set to Appeal in YouTube Case
summary: Viacom says a new wave of digital piracy could threaten the U.S. media business unless federal courts overturn its defeat in a copyright-infringement lawsuit against Google's YouTube video-sharing site.

headline: Tax Breaks for Bailout Recipients Spark Debate
summary: A series of tax relief measures is saving companies bailed out by the government like GM, Citigroup and AIG billions of dollars at a time when concern over tax revenues has risen.

headline: UniCredit to Expand in Europe
summary: UniCredit plans to open 900 new branches in Central and Eastern Europe in the next five years to significantly bolster its role as the leading bank in the region.

headline: Accused Spam King to Be Arraigned
summary: A 23-year-old Russian man accused by U.S. authorities of generating nearly a third of the spam emails world-wide is expected to be arraigned Friday in a Milwaukee court.

headline: Draka Battle Turns Political
summary: The takeover battle for Draka is turning political amid fears that China's activity and Europe's tough stance on cartels could undermine European cable makers' global competitiveness.

headline: A Shopping Site Built for You
summary: Boutiques.com, a personalized shopping site recently launched by Google, analyzes your fashion style and creates a customized "boutique."

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: LeBron Overcomes the Boos in Cleveland
summary: LeBron James overcame the boos in his first return to Cleveland, as he scored a game-high 38 points in the Miami Heat's 118-90 win over the Cavaliers.

headline: Oscar Farinetti Mixes Business With Pleasure
summary: The founder of gourmet food and wine hall Eataly talks about how he starts his weekend.

headline: Competence Test
summary: After the crash, it seems, at least a handful will find there are no second acts in City life.

headline: Exploring Science Through Art
summary: After a decade of relative obscurity, science-inspired artists such as Katherine Dowson and David Marron are winning public attention and attracting collectors.

headline: Good Jobs News Hardly Merits a Celebration
summary: Even if the U.S. labor market is picking up steam, the battered ship is miles away from port.

headline: Chinese Viewers Send Out for Thai Drama
summary: Thai soap operas -- over-the-top potboilers -- are the latest sensation in China, as Asia starts to outgrow its addiction to Hollywood hand-me-downs.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Yale Law professor Stephen L. Carter warns that it would be difficult to prosecute WikiLeaks without also prosecuting newspapers.

headline: Rangel Censured for Ethics Violations
summary: The House voted to impose the rarely used punishment of censure on New York Democratic Rep. Charles Rangel for nearly a dozen ethics violations.

headline: A Different Kind of Broadway Twofer
summary: Now ticket buyers get more for their money—everything from archival exhibitions to cucumber sandwiches.

headline: U.S. Sees Greater North Korea Threat
summary: The Obama administration told the United Nations nuclear watchdog that North Korea likely has built more than one uranium-enrichment facility, significantly raising the proliferation threat posed by the secretive communist state.

headline: How Do We Evaluate and Improve School Performance?
summary: Diane Ravitch is certainly qualified by achievement and experience to critique America's effort's to reform the dismal state of its public school system "The GOP's Education Dilemma" (op-ed, Nov. 29). However, her recommendation that we follow the example of Finland, Japan and South Korea is naive.

headline: Information on the Lam
summary: America's latest insider trading case is eerily similar to China's ongoing suppression of market information.

headline: BP Spill-Panel Staff Cites Failings
summary: A "failure of management" by BP and its contractors led to moves designed to save time and increase efficiency that heightened blowout risks prior to the deadly rig explosion that set off the Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

headline: Marvin Hier and Abraham Cooper: Presbyterians Against Israel
summary: Liberal Protestants are engaging in historical revisionism concerning Jews and the Holy Land.

headline: Soda Ban Gets a Key Backer
summary: Bucking his traditional supporters, Public Advocate Bill de Blasio is endorsing Mayor Michael Bloomberg's proposal to bar recipients of food stamps from using them to buy soda or other sugar-sweetened drinks.

headline: A Kitchen to Comfort the Soul
summary: Combining psychology and neuroscience, interior desinger Johnny Grey brings emotional, physical and psychological well-being into kitchen planning.

headline: Old Masters Show Their Muscle
summary: Old Masters will be the highlight of London auctions next week, including a major religious work by Nicolas Poussin, portraits by Anthony van Dyck and Italian views by Canaletto.

headline: At Basel, the Art of Party-Hopping
summary: Party-hopping at Art Basel is a little tedious, but that doesn't stop anyone from doing it. There are too many events, indistinguishable from each other except, by the brand of champagne being uncorked.

headline: Giants Debate When It's OK to Laugh It Off
summary: There's no crying in baseball. But what about laughing in football?

headline: Pepsi to Buy Russian Drinks Giant
summary: PepsiCo is buying Russian dairy products and fruit-juice maker Wimm-Bill-Dann in a deal valuing the company at $5.4 billion.

headline: Coolhunter: The Christmas Tree Project
summary: When Fabien Cappello graduated from the Royal College of Art in 2009, his degree show featured stools fashioned from abandoned Christmas trees. Why has no one thought of this before?

headline: Politicos Get Colorful After World Cup Vote
summary: British and Russian politicians weigh in on the World Cup vote. Plus, bowling alleys are seeing a boom in kid participants, and The Couch gets set for the SEC Championship game.

headline: Her Face Was Her Misfortune
summary: Two books on actress Hedy Lamarr that ponder how her roles became limited by her unlimited beauty. Jeanine Basinger reviews.

headline: The Changing Face of German Bunds
summary: Nothing the European Central Bank said Thursday is likely to end the euro sovereign crisis. One result: German Bunds may continue to shed their safe-haven status.

headline: Builders Mark Time on Outlet Centers
summary: Mall developers, desperate for growth, are rushing downscale to build outlet centers that hawk brand-name clothes at discount prices. Construction of traditional malls is at a standstill in the current economy.

headline: Opposition Wins Ivory Coast Presidency
summary: Opposition candidate Alassane Ouattara won the Ivory Coast presidential runoff election after a tense delay sparked violence in the West African nation.

headline: CORRECTION
summary: The California Public Employees' Retirement System (Calpers) said it was cutting ties with Pacific Corporate Group as part of an "ongoing strategic review" of its private-equity program and investment partners, amid criticism of the pension fund for poor returns and conflict-of-interest questions. An Oct. 13 editorial, "Scoundrels and Pensions," said Calpers cut ties with PCG because of pay-to-play concerns.

headline: John Fund: Government By Executive Order
summary: A new Labor Department plan shows the president still has wide power to implement an anti-business agenda.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Dec. 3, 2010

headline: Momenta Sues Teva Over Patents For Heparin
summary: Momenta sued Teva over patents related to the blockbuster rapid-acting heparin called enoxaparin.

headline: Rangel's Censure
summary: The 23rd Member to be so dishonored.

headline: New Link in Chain of Life
summary: Researchers said they had created microbes that "very likely" use arsenic in their DNA in place of phosphorus, in what may be the first exception to the formula long thought to govern the basic chemistry of life.

headline: 'Swan' Takes Horror to Lurid Heights
summary: Natalie Portman's ballerina grounds "Black Swan" in reality, while Jim Carrey, as a gay con man, lights up "I Love You Phillip Morris."

headline: How to Shrink the Deficit
summary: President Obama's deficit commission lands with a predictable political thud.

headline: Furthering Jewish Study at Rutgers
summary: The head of the Shevell Group of Companies will Tuesday announce a $500,000 donation to the Chabad House Jewish Student Center at Rutgers University.

headline: SEC Delays Plans for Whistleblower Office
summary: Agency officials said they can't do the work without a funding increase, and Republicans, who will control the House next year, may not be sympathetic to their pleas.

headline: With a Rhythm in His Heart
summary: Randy Weston's forebears are never far from his music.

headline: Dow Chemical Hit Again on Bhopal
summary: India's attorney general asked the nation's supreme court to force Dow Chemical to pay $1.1 billion more in victims' compensation and cleanup costs related to the 1984 Bhopal disaster.

headline: Gerald P. O'Driscoll Jr.: Why Do We Have a Central Bank?
summary: Ordinary citizens will increasingly ask that question if the Fed keeps acting as an unelected fiscal authority.

headline: Cookie News
summary: From Momofuku-by-mail to an ultimate cookie cookbook, a roundup of what milk's better half has been up to.

headline: A Gateway Exhibition
summary: Every society is a "High Society," at least occasionally. Our own culture, argues the exhibition with this title at London's Wellcome Collection, uses legal mind-altering drugs constantly and every day, from our wake-up cup of tea or coffee to our bedtime cocoa.

headline: Down Under, Summing Up
summary: In "Lazarus Rising," former Australian Prime Minister John Howard explains how his party steadily shed the web of big government and protectionism and opened Australia up to immigration and market competition. Mary Kissel reviews.
